div.p: kunaṅ hulaha saṅ prabhu, uniṅānira taṅ vyavahāranikaṅ rāt, harovaṅa ta sira brāhmaṇa vihikan maṅaji, lavan mantri vruhmantri riṁ vruḥmantri, vruḥ mavivekāmavikvekā, sulakṣaṇaha ta sira tumamaha riṅ sabhā.

haliṅgihāpagəhahaliṅgih apagəhahaliṅgiḥ pagəha: ta sira riṅ sabhā, taṅanira tṅən hatah ulahakniraula:knira, hayvātuduh-tuduhhayva tuduḥtuduḥ kiva, bhūṣaṇa-pahyasniṅ vvaṅ suśīlātah lviranira, iṅət-iṅətənirātah yogyāyogyani kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

strīpuṁdharmo, the next ground of litigation in Manu’s list, is expected here, along with the paraphrase belonging to it. Is it understood to be implied in the item [strī]saṁgrahaṇam? Or are we dealing with an omission in our two witnesses that does not reflect the original state of our text? vibhāgaśvinagaś ca, kadumaniṅ dr̥vya. dyūtamdyuta, totohan tan prāṇi. āhvānamAhvanam·The vulgate reading of MānDhŚ is āhvaya here, but several mss. used by Olivelle2005_01 share the reading with n that seems to have been received on Bali., totohan prāṇi. padāny aṣṭādaśaitānipada AṣṭadaśetaniAṣṭadasetani, nahan ta vvaluva:luvalu vlas lvirnya. vyavahārasthitānīhavyava:hara:sthita:nihavyavahara:stitanihaThe vulgate reading of MānDhŚ is vyavahārasthitāv iha here, but it seems that the text received on Bali had the (unmetrical) reading that we adopt here. Olivelle’s ms. Be1 has the variant -sthitāni ca., byakta pinakasthānaniṅpinaka:stana: vyavahāra.

eṣu sthāneṣu bhūyiṣṭhamEvustha:neṣṭabhuya:ṣṭiṁUvustha:neṣṭabhūyaśṭaṃ, ikaṅ vyavahārasthāna vvaluva:luvalu vlas, kapva hana katmunyata tmunya ṅkana, kapagəhakna saṅ prabhu, yuktinikaṅ vyavahāranya, apan gavayaknanira pagəh i kāryanikaṅnikā yogya pagəhaknanira.
kunaṅ saṅ prabhu hayva sira gumavayakən ikaṅ kāryāmivakṣa guṇadoṣa, hakona ta sira ririṁ saṅ brāhmaṇaprabrahmaṇna vihikan maṅajiaṅaji, kumavruhana yogyanikaṅ vvaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

list.item: This stanza is absent from Olivelle's constituted text, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for ms. Ox2 after 8.9. Mandlik (p. 877) and Jha include the stanza at the beginning of Medhātithi’s comment on 8.9; in his notes, Jha (v. 9, p. 490) cites citations of this verse in medieval scholastic works. In contrast with the cases in Div. XX and YY, van Naerssen (1956) did not notice that the Old Javanese text here implies the presence of this stanza because the Sanskrit original is not quoted.

div.p: saṅ brāhmaṇa saṅ vruh riṅ aṣṭādaśavyavahāra, sira ta saṅ sinaṅguh prāgvivākaThe word is consistently spelled pragvivakā in both manuscipts., saṅ vruh riṅ aji tarkatanka vruha riṅ śruti veda. kunaṅ ikaṅ tantraniṅ vicāra, gavayakna rumuhun, sādhana saṅ prāgvivāka matakvanpatakvan irikaṅikaṁ mavyavahāra kalih, vivekanira ta sahurnya vkasan, mataṅhyan prāgvivāka pva ṅaranira.

haṅiṅət-iṅəta tahaṅiṅətiṅəttha saṅ prāgvivāka, hi kāryanikaṅhinaryyanikaṁ mavyavahāra kalih, harovaṅa ta sira vvaṅ yogya riṅ sabhāsana: tigaṅ viji, tumamahajumamaha: ta sirāluṅguhāpagəhasira:luṅguḥhapagəhasiraluṅguḥhapagəhaIt would also be possible to interpet the manuscript evidence as supporting sirāluṅguh apagəha, with irrealis suffix only on the second form. riṅ sabhā.

saṅ brāhmaṇa tigaṅ siki, paḍa vruh maṅaji, hana brāhmaṇa sasiki prajñān vidagdha, vinidhi muṅgva riṅ deśa saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ deśa papupulanira, yeka deśa sabhā ṅaranya de saṅ paṇḍitayeka de saṁ paṇḍita .

ikaṅ sabhāśana:, yan tan ana saṅ vr̥ddhah tan sabhā ṅaranya, saṅ vr̥ddhah yan tan vruh iṅriṅ dharma, tan vr̥ddhaḥ ṅaranira, saṅ vruh iṅriṅ dharma yan tan agəgvanaBoth mss. present an irrealis here. Emend agəgvan? kajātyan, tan dharma ṅaranikā, kunaṅ yan tan ginavayakəngina§

kunaṅ hikaṅ vvaṅ haṅujarakən prāya yukti, salah denya vkasan, makveh ujarnya, vvaṅ katon doṣanyaḍeṣanya, ika ta kabeh tan yogya tumamaha riṅ sabhā.

mataṅyan maṅkana, dharmanika saṅ uniṅa riṅ dharma, hilaṅ ikā deniṅ adharma riṅ sabhā, kasatyanirakasaktyanira maṅkanātah hilaṅnikā deniṅ adva riṅ sabhā, yapvan alah juga dharma deniṅ adharma, halah juga satya deniṅ adva, paḍa hana pva ya riṅ sabhā, patimbunaniṅpatambunaniṁ kunapa ṅaraniṅ sabhā yan maṅkana.

kunaṅ yan iṅilaṅakən saṅ hyaṅ dharma, malǝs juga sira maṅilaṅakən, yan rinakṣa saṅ hyaṅ dharma malǝs juga sira maṅrakṣamarakṣa, mataṅyanmataṅhyan·mataṅhya maṅkana, hayvāṅilaṅakən dharma, liṅniṅ vvaṅ, tan paṅilaṅakən pva kita dharma, tan paṅilaṅakən sira hiri ya, maṅkanamaṅka liṅ atǝhər pramāṇastavapraṇama:stavapraṇama:stava.

div.p: apan tan ana dharma lena sakeṅ kasatyan, iya dharma, iya satya, tan ana pāpapa:pan lenlekanOr emend lena, as just previously? sakeṅsakiṁṅ hadva, iya pāpa, iya hadva, saṅhārasaṅara ṅaranika kalih, mataṅyan ta pagəh ikaṅ lokaloka:ṁleka:, dharma hetunikā, hayomataṅhyan tan yogya hiṅilaṅakǝn saṅ hyaṅ dharma dedḍera saṅ mahyun məntasa.

ikaṅ vvaṅ magave hala, vruh pva yan alaahala gavenya, tan ana kumavruhi ry akuyyaku, maṅkana kaharǝpnyakaR̥p·nya madva, valiṅnya tan ana mulati hiriyariya, tan vruh pvatan· pvatan vruḥ pa yan saṅ hyaṅ ātma haneriya, kumavruhi sapolahnya, mataṅyan takvanǝntakvanWe cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanǝn is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanǝn ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 27. ikaṅ ulahika hulaḥ salah vkasan de saṅ prāgvivāka, yadyapi vinunivanuni.

div.p: kunaṅ sakaton sakarǝṅə̄ dentasakaR̥ṅəntenta sākṣi, yen tuhu, śīghrakunaṅ sakaton ... śīghrakunaṁ yan satya: kitta:, sakaton sakaR̥ṅə: denta:, tuhuta:, śigr̥The two witnesses offer two alternative ways of expressing essentially the same meaning. ujaraknanta, kapaṅguh ikaṅ svarga denta, mvaṅ kamokṣan, pasaṅgrahan, maṅkana liṅ saṅ prāgvivāka riṅ sākṣi.For the paraphrase of the second hemistisch of the Sanskrit stanza, see .

inujaran pvekaṅ sākṣi maṅkana de saṅ prāgvivāka, vulatananira ta ya pituṅ vai lavasanya, katkankavkan· pva hikaṅ sākṣi lara, katunvan umahnya kunaṅ,lara: kunaṁ katunvan umaḥnya, hikaṅ hutaṅ pinaṅguḥnyasinaṅguḥnya tuhu, pan ḍaṇḍapandaṇḍaWe reject a prima facie interpretation as paṇḍaṇḍa, since the only occurrences of such a word known to us from other texts are spelt paṅḍaṇḍa and it would anyhow not make sense in the context. ikaṅ sākṣi.

When the king is going to try a case, he should enter the court modestly accompanied by Brahmins and counselors who are experts in policy Now should his Majesty undertake to attend to litigation/affairs of this world, let him take as companions Brahmins who are knowledgeable and study Scripture, and likewise ministers with the wisdom to judge with discernment; with good conduct, he should enter the council.
